data.text:
Bill Gates is the founder and former CEO of technology giant Microsoft. He also founded the philanthropic Bill Gates Foundation, known since Gates’s marriage to Melinda Gates (nee French) as the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.

Since founding Microsoft in the 1970s, Gates has become one of the world’s wealthiest and most influential individuals, previously holding the title of world’s wealthiest person. His “Giving Pledge” to give away all of his money during his lifetime inspired a number of the world’s billionaires to promise to do the same, including investor and fellow left-leaning business leader Warren Buffett.

Personal Life

Gates was one of three children raised in Seattle, Washington by a business executive mother and attorney father. He began writing computer software by the time he was in junior high, and in high school co-founded his first small business, Traf-O-Data, a traffic-counting system with his future Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen.

In 1975, Gates dropped out of Harvard University so that he and Allen could write software for personal computers, then called “microcomputers.” Allen and Gates later founded Microsoft, which turned Gates into the world’s then-youngest-ever billionaire at 31 and, by the time he was 39, the world’s wealthiest man.

Gates is also a best-selling author, being credited with authoring The Road Ahead. Written in 1995, it was a New York Times bestseller which examined the future of the computer world, including the then-new internet. In 1999, Gates authored Business @ the Speed of Thought, also a bestseller.

Bill Gates met his future wife in 1987 when she began working at Microsoft. They were married in 1994, when he was 38 and she was 29. They reportedly got engaged after Gates put the pros and cons of marrying Melinda on a whiteboard. They have three children and share co-chair positions in the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation with Bill’s father.

U2 frontman Bono and the Gates’ were named Time Persons of the Year in 2005 for their charitable work.

Microsoft

Early Years

Gates founded Microsoft with Allen in 1975 in Arizona. While many other companies focused on the then-new computer age’s hardware, Microsoft became a leader in software. The company was founded as Micro-Soft before the hyphen was removed. It earned over a $1 million in annual revenue by 1978. It grossed $16 million by 1981.

Microsoft was moved to Seattle, Washington in 1979, where it became a leader in the early era of computer software. Its first major client was IBM, after Gates purchased a third-party company’s software program, changed it to become MS-DOS software, and licensed it to IBM. Microsoft’s licensing model eventually became its major revenue generator. Gates’ mother allegedly helped Microsoft land its initial IBM deal.

By 1983, 30 percent of the world’s computers were run on Microsoft software and the company had offices in several countries. This was also the year in which poor health forced Allen to leave Microsoft. Two years later, Microsoft launched its Windows program to beat out competitor Apple, leading to a lawsuit which lasted for years. Apple accused Microsoft of illegally basing Windows off of Apple’s new Macintosh system. Apple’s lawsuit was eventually thrown out in court in the 1990s.

In 1989, Microsoft had improved its Windows program and launched the Microsoft Office suite of programs. It also went public in 1986, generating $61 million with its initial public offering. By the mid-1990s, Windows programs were running on 85 percent of the world’s computers, and in 1999 it grossed nearly $20 billion per year, with Gates’ wealth estimated at $90 billion. Gates held the status of world’s wealthiest person until 2008, a title he has reclaimed periodically including in 2019 thanks to Microsoft’s strong performance that year.

Litigation

Microsoft was federally sued for illegal monopolist practices in 1998, and the company was found guilty in court in 1999. A 2002 settlement led to changes in the company’s processes, though lawsuits elsewhere have continued. Microsoft was also sued by 20 state Attorneys General for the same reason.

Fall from Peak

Legal troubles were just the start to more than 10 years of Microsoft’s struggles. The changing customer market, competition, and transitions to online technologies hurt the company. Several poor product launches, an allegedly poor company culture under CEO Steve Ballmer, and other factors hurt its growth and its dominance in the market. However, under new CEO Satya Nadella, the company grossed over $125 billion in 2019, in part thanks to buyouts of companies like Skype and GitHub, but also due to more successful adjustments to the 21st century computer world.

The company also secured a $10 billion Department of Defense contract in 2019, though a lawsuit from Amazon held up the contract as of early 2020. Amazon claims that the contract bidding process was unfair because of President Donald Trump’s attacks on Amazon and its CEO, Jeff Bezos.

In addition to its technology and business leadership, Microsoft is also a major participant in left-of-center philanthropic activity. Its direct and indirect financial and hardware donations totaled more than $2 billion in 2019, with tens of millions more dollars promised for future endeavors. The company is engaged in dozens of nations in a variety of technology, environmentalist, educational, and other efforts, including supporting the Paris Climate Accords and engaging in water security endeavors.

Microsoft also engages directly in politics. Its political action committee donated to dozens of congressional candidates in both parties in the first half of 2019, totaling $274,000, and it made over $112,000 in corporate political organization donations during the same time period. In 2018, the company spent approximately eight million dollars and nine million dollars to influence state and federal policies, respectively.

Microsoft company culture regularly reflects its technology industry and Pacific Northwest cultures. The company prizes diversity, including support of the LGBT movement.

Gates has held several roles at Microsoft since 2000. He stepped down as CEO that year and became chief software architect until 2008, at which point he stepped down to focus more on philanthropy. He was board chair until 2014, at which point he became a board member and a technology advisor. He is one of only three people who have served as CEO of Microsoft; Steve Ballmer held the position from 2000 to 2014, and Satya Nadella has held it since 2014.

Gates formally stepped down from Microsoft’s board and from the board of Warren Buffett’s investment firm Berkshire Hathaway in March 2020.

Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation

The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation is the world’s largest private foundation as of April 2020, with assets totaling $46 billion. Originally, the Foundation was named for Bill Gates’ father, William H. Gates, who managed the Foundation’s day-to-day operations before becoming co-chair.

The Foundation engages in five broad categories of philanthropy :

Health, focusing on infectious disease and child mortality in developing countries.

Development, focusing on health coverage and products in poor communities.

Growth and opportunity, focusing on innovative business and other engagements.

S. education, focused on high schools and colleges, as well as “vulnerable children and families in Washington State.”

Policy and advocacy, creating partnerships and promoting policies to advance the Foundation’s work.

Most of the Foundation’s work is not obviously politicized, focusing on health issues like malaria prevention and treatment, vaccine development and distribution, and combatting HIV/AIDS overseas. In 2010, the Gates pledged $10 billion to vaccine research, testing, creation, and more by 2020. Both Gates and the Foundation received significant attention in 2020 during the COVID-19 pandemic because of Gates’ support for social distancing and vaccines, as well as a coronavirus vaccine which the Foundation helped fund into testing. The Foundation is also funding the creation of seven centers to mass-produce a COVID-19 vaccine once one has been developed.

The Foundation has coordinated, organized, and/or influenced the creation of major international no-governmental organizations which are dedicated to its areas of focus, especially health care and vaccination.

However, the Foundation has drawn criticism for its “gender equality” and “women’s empowerment” efforts, especially its family planning and contraception campaigns, from abortion advocates and opponents. The organization has funded abortion groups such as International Planned Parenthood. While its funding is earmarked to not be used for abortions, pro-life advocates have argued that its funding still facilitates abortions. Melinda Gates, however, wrote in 2014 that abortion is a separate issue from birth control, leading to criticism from abortion advocates.

The Foundation also helped develop Common Core education standards as part of its billions in education investments, and worked with the Obama administration to implement them.

As of December 31, 2018, the Foundation employed nearly 1,500 people, had given over $50 billion in grants, and gave $5 billion in grants in 2018. One of its major funders and trustees is investor Warren Buffett, who has pledged to donate over $31 billion to the Foundation and has donated at least $1.3 billion annually to the Foundation since 2006, with $2.6 billion donated in 2018.

Other Work

Gates founded Cascade Investments, in which he holds both his personal and the Foundation’s investments. He also founded TerraPower, a research group focused on creating more nuclear energy.

Bill and Melinda Gates and Warren Buffett created the Giving Pledge in 2010. It is a non-binding promise made by billionaires or those who would be billionaires if not for philanthropic efforts to give away most of their money either before they die or in their wills. There are approximately 200 signatories from around the world.

Gates is involved in a number of business ventures, including, but not limited to, being the largest shareholder in AutoNation. He was an early investor in the satellite-based video start-up EarthNow. He owns the philanthropic and business incubator Gates Ventures, which was originally founded in 2008 as a think tank.

Gates runs a private blog, GatesNotes.

Political Views and Engagement

Gates’ political views appear to be mixed. He is famous for supporting intellectual property rights, a viewpoint which is anathema to many “open source” liberals and to a significant percentage of coders, software engineers, and others in the technology space.

Gates believes that climate change is a major threat to humanity, and has focused major Foundation attention and money to the issue. He wrote a book which is set for publication in 2021 about climate change. He supports Common Core education standards and opposed the Trump administration’s Mexico City Policy, which prohibits federal funds from supporting organizations that advocate for abortions.

Gates criticized U.S. Senator Elizabeth Warren’s (D-MA) wealth tax and said he would consider voting for President Trump if she were the Democratic nominee. However, he supports taxing the wealthy as part of a progressive tax system.

Gates also criticized the Trump administration’s withdrawal of money from the World Health Organization after the international organization used misleading Chinese government data about the COVID-19 pandemic. He and Melinda wrote in 2018 that they support same-sex relationships and self-described gender definitions. Gates has held meetings with President Donald Trump, including one in 2018 to urge the president to support greater U.S. foreign aid. He also discussed vaccines, innovation, education, and other issues with Trump in another meeting.

Gates is also supportive of the idea that Earth is overpopulated. He and Melinda responded in 2018 to the idea that by saving children’s lives in poor nations they are contributing to overpopulation. Gates’ father led a chapter of Planned Parenthood, and he has spoken well of the abortion group in addition to providing contraceptive and abortifacient funds to abortion groups internationally.

In February 2021, during an interview on “60 Minutes,” Gates told Anderson Cooper that the world should reduce its carbon emissions to zero, saying it would be “the most amazing thing mankind has ever done.” Just a month earlier, Gates joined a bidding war to buy the world’s largest private jet company, despite private jets being some of the world’s greatest carbon emitters.

Controversies

Previous Ties to Jeffrey Epstein

A May 2023 Wall Street Journal article reported that several individuals, who say they are “familiar with the matter,” made claims that Gates had allegedly been involved in an affair with Russian bridge player Mila Antonova before being threatened by deceased sex offender and financier Jeffrey Epstein over revealing said affair. According to Antonova, she had first met Gates in 2010 at a bridge card game tournament in the United States. Anatonova had previously studied in Russia from 2000 to 2005 but later moved to the U.S where she founded a local Bridge club and later became a software engineer. She first met with Epstein in 2013, after being introduced by then-Gates scientific advisor Boris Nikolic, for help with raising money to start an online venture for teaching people how to play bridge. Though failing to raise money, she allegedly stayed at Epstein’s New York townhouse for a brief time and in 2014 Epstein paid for her tuition at a programming school. She commented, “Epstein agreed to pay and he paid directly to the school. Nothing was exchanged. I don’t know why he did that…When I asked, he said something like, he was wealthy and wanted to help people when he could.”

According to the same people “familiar with the matter,” in 2017 Epstein had emailed Gates to ask for a reimbursement of payments for Antonova and the programming school. According to a spokesperson for Gates, “Mr. Gates met with Epstein solely for philanthropic purposes. Having failed repeatedly to draw Mr. Gates beyond these matters, Epstein tried unsuccessfully to leverage a past relationship to threaten Mr. Gates.” The spokesperson also commented, “Mr. Gates had no financial dealings with Epstein.” When interviewed, Antonova refused to comment on Gates but said of Epstein, “I had no idea that he was a criminal or had any ulterior motive…I just thought he was a successful businessman and wanted to help…I am disgusted with Epstein and what he did.”

According to the Wall Street Journal, Gates had previously met with Epstein at least half a dozen times since 2011, from dinners at Epstein’s New York home, meeting in France in 2013 with a Nobel Prize Committee official, and both had flown on Epstein’s private jet in March 2013 from New Jersey to Florida. In addition, Nikolic revealed to the Wall Street Journal that shortly before his death in 2019, Epstein had named Nickolic as a “backup executor” to his will, though he refused. Nikolic claimed Epstein, “couldn’t have listed Bill because that would have been too obvious, so he chose me…I have come to believe it was likely a retaliatory move against Bill Gates.”

Legacy

Bill Gates’ impact through business, philanthropy, and politics has been significant. Microsoft defined the burgeoning computer industry for 25 years and continues to impact the technology industry, businesses, and consumers. Gates has accomplished his original goal of putting a computer in every home, as well as in government agencies, educational facilities, and elsewhere throughout the world.

However, Gates’ record is and will continue to be controversial in certain circles. He was accused by government agencies around the world and competitors of engaging in cutthroat, often unethical, practices as Microsoft CEO, which led to lawsuits and other actions. His left-of-center political views make him controversial among conservatives. Meanwhile, left-of-center political observers and academics have accused the Foundation of putting its own priorities, and those of corporations, in front of the real needs of those to whom it is providing assistance.

Gates was briefly associated with convicted sex trafficker and alleged child sex abuser Jeffrey Epstein in media reports after Epstein’s death; Gates and Epstein reportedly discussed a possible fundraising partnership for the Gates Foundation. Gates claims the conversations went nowhere.
